awd_titl_txt: QII-TAQS: Simulating Entangled Quantum Chemical Abstract Machines
awd_abstract_narration:
The coupled quantum-mechanical behavior of protons and electrons has a central role in many chemical catalytic reactions that are fundamental to human existence. A critical portion of this project will involve the mapping of the quantum mechanical descriptions of complex chemical catalysis problems to a specialized type of quantum computer, known as an ion-trap quantum simulator.  This map will be used to develop quantum software and domain-specific computing tools.  These tools are inspired by a popular and influential model of computation, known as the chemical abstract machine. The research project will design, build, and validate the effectiveness of a general programming model with a variety of existing quantum algorithms and applying the models to problems in chemical catalysis. Broader impacts include new quantum science directed graduate, undergraduate, and postdoctoral training initiatives in physics, chemistry, and computer science. Furthermore, summer workshops on quantum science for local middle- and high- school science teachers will also be initiated. Underrepresented groups, including women, will be recruited into computational and physical sciences.

An integrated quantum simulation ecosystem that includes a mathematical description, a computational implementation, and an experimental realization of a challenging quantum problem in chemical catalysis will be developed. This includes an integrated domain-specific programming paradigm, a quantum simulator, and associated quantum algorithms that facilitate the mapping and consequently the study of complex chemical catalysis problems. Dissipative molecular system-bath Hamiltonians will be mapped to ion-lattice quantum simulator Hamiltonians.  This will be used to develop chemical abstract machine-based quantum software to program the time evolution of coupled electron-proton states arising from a set of synthetic proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) problems on the quantum simulator. The validation of quantum simulation will be conducted through the experimental investigations of a modular set of intramolecular PCET platforms and a combination of quantum dynamics and electronic structure calculations on the smaller model systems. 

This project is jointly funded by Quantum Leap Big Idea Program and the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The accurate computational determination of molecular properties, including reactivity of chemical, materials, biological and atmospheric problems has had a critical impact on a wide range of areas including those that affect our health and our environment. Indeed computational modeling of molecular systems are routinely used in (a) the study of the critical interactions involved in biologically relevant processes such as the interaction of drug-like molecules and vaccines with targets, and active site binding processes that facilitate drug-receptor interactions, (b) the effect of atmospheric pollutants on chemical processes critical to our environment and safety, (c) the study of catalysts that have the potential to fuel an energy efficient economy, (d) the study of new fertilizer technologies to reduce the adverse effect of chemical by-products on our environment, (e) new battery technologies, and (f) molecular recognition processes in environmental and biological sensor technologies. These are only a few of the larger number of  applications affected by accurate modeling of chemical processes.  

In all cases above, however, the accurate computational determination of molecular properties necessary to effectively carry out predictive and reliable molecular simulations is severely affected by the steep computational scaling of accurate quantum mechanical methods. That is, computing the properties of molecules and biological assemblies using the principles of quantum mechanics is really very hard. But if one were to be able to carry out such studies, we could make crtical progress in the study of the above listed set of challenges. The complexity of quantum-chemical studies arises from the steep computational scaling of electron correlation methods, and dynamics of nuclei. Due to these reasons, quantum computing has been thought to be one way to study such complex chemical proceses.

Towards this, as part of this project, our strongly inter-disciplinary team of quantum chemists, atomic physicists, computer scientists and inorganic chemists have developed a quantum simulator, and associated set of quantum computing algorithms and have used these to study chemical processes on ion-trap quantum computers. As part of our research, we have developed a framework which allows for the solution of quantum chemical nuclear dynamics problems on ion-trap quantum computers. We have implemented this framework on commercial ion-trap quantum computers (IonQ) and also on Sandia national labs's QSCOUT system. We believe our new quantum algorithms may provide a new paradign form studying complex chemical processes. 

Key Outcomes are outlined in the following paragraphs:

As part of our research, we have developed a framework which allows for the solution of quantum chemical dynamics by mapping these to quantum spin-lattice simulators. We have implemented this framework on Sandia national labs' QSCOUT ion-trap quantum computer with very good agreement in accuracy between the quantum computing results and those obtained using classical comuters.

We have developed the first parallel quantum algorithm for computing chemical dynamics and we have implemented these on IonQ's 11-qubit Harmony ion-trap quantum computer.

We have shown a close connection between the mathematical description behind prime-factorin algorithms and quantum chemical dynamics. This is a new avenue that was not proposed, buy developed due to the close interactions between quantum chemists, atomic physicists and theoretical computer scientists.

We have been constructing an ion-trap apparatus capable of implementing quantum dynamics simulations in-house at Indiana. Ion confinement has now been achieved, with stable configurations up to 29 ions demonstrated. 

We have worked to address the need for a high-level notation for quantum algorithms together with a logic for reasoning about and optimizing quantum programs. The work is adapting ideas from categorytheory to develop quantum programming building blocks and is a first step towards defining quantum programming languages with rich algebraic datatypes, higher-order functions, and computational effects.

In the direction of also developing complex chemistries that need to be studied with such advacned computational platforms, we have also discovered an unusual alkene isomerization catalyst. We are in the process of studying this complex problem using the algorithms discussed above. 

In education and outreach, we have shown that it is possible to communicate the complex intricacies of quantum computing using a game of darts. A paper describing this effort, with a high-school student as first author has been published and additional high-school student participants are currently pushing this idea with the PI.

  • Quantum dynamics with wavepackets is classically intractable and a promising avenue for quantum information processing. We provide the first application of distributed quantum computing for chemical dynamics problems and implement our algorithm on IonQ's 11-qubit Harmony system.

    Quantum nuclear dynamics on a distributed set of ion-trap quantum computing systems
  • By constructing a higher-dimensional ion trap quantum simulator, one can begin to address many of the open questions in quantum many-body physics and quantum chemistry.
    New Journal of Physics 26, 023033 (2024)
    Copyrighted
    Srinivasan S Iyengar
    Camera image of a Ytterbium ion chain in a Paul trap
  • Calculating observable properties of chemical systems is often classically intractable and widely viewed as a promising application of quantum information processing. Here, we introduce a new framework for solving generic quantum chemical dynamics problems using quantum logic.
    J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 14, 7256 (2023)
    Copyrighted
    Srinivasan S Iyengar
    Vibrational spectra of molecules obtained from ion-trap quantum computing
  • The accurate computation of chemical, materials, biological, and atmospheric properties is limited by the cost of quantum-mechanical methods. We show that Hamiltonians for the nuclear dynamics can be mapped to Ising Hamiltonians that can be implemented on a range of quantum computing systems.
    J. Chem. Theory and Comput. 17, 6713 (2021).
    Copyrighted
    Srinivasan S Iyengar
    Mapping chemical dynamics problems to ion-lattice systems
  • We describe a general formalism for quantum dynamics and show how this formalism subsumes several quantum algorithms including the Deutsch, Deutsch-Jozsa, Bernstein-Vazirani, Simon, and Shor algorithms as well as the conventional approach to quantum dynamics based on tensor networks.
    J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2023, 19, 18, 6082�6092
    Copyrighted
    Srinivasan S Iyengar
    A Synthesis of Hidden Subgroup Quantum Algorithms and Quantum Chemical Dynamics
